title: 4 Simple Ways to Turn Off Safe Mode on Any Android

steps.title: Press and hold your Android's Power button.
steps.content: Press and hold your Android's Power button. The Power button is usually on the right side of the Android's housing.

steps.title: Tap Power off when prompted.
steps.content: Tap Power off when prompted. Doing so will prompt your Android to begin shutting down. You may have to tap Power off again to confirm this decision. Alternatively, you can tap Restart to restart your phone.

steps.title: Wait for your Android to shut down completely.
steps.content: Wait for your Android to shut down completely. This process will take a few minutes.

steps.title: Turn back on your Android.
steps.content: Turn back on your Android. Press and hold the Power button until you see your Android's boot screen, then release the button. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Wait for your Android to finish restarting.
steps.content: Wait for your Android to finish restarting. Once your Android turns back on, it should no longer be in Safe Mode. If your Android is still in Safe Mode, press and hold the Power button and Volume Up buttons for about 30 seconds until your phone shuts off. Then turn it back on. If your phone is stuck in Safe Mode, one of the buttons may be stuck. Remove your phone from its case and press each of the buttons on the side of your phone. This includes the Power button and both Volume buttons. Make sure no buttons are stuck. If the problem continues, you may have a corrupted app. You'll need to uninstall it in Safe Mode .

steps.title: Swipe down from the top of the screen.
steps.content: Swipe down from the top of the screen. On some phone models, you can turn off Safe Mode using the notifications panel. Swipe down from the top of the menu to display your notifications.

steps.title: Tap the "Safe mode is turned on" notification if available.
steps.content: Tap the "Safe mode is turned on" notification if available. It should be at the top of your list of notifications. If you don't see this notification, this option is not available on your phone model.

steps.title: Tap Turn off.
steps.content: Tap Turn off . It should be in the Safe Mode notification. This will restart your phone. When it boots up again, Safe Mode should be turned off.

steps.title: Make sure you know which app is causing trouble.
steps.content: Make sure you know which app is causing trouble. A corrupted or malicious app is the most common reason for Android phones or tablets to boot into Safe Mode. If your Android had never booted into Safe Mode until you installed a certain app, that app is probably the reason. [2] X Research source Uninstalling bad apps can be a bit of a trial-and-error process, so start with any apps that load immediately when your Android starts up (e.g., Home Screen widgets). You can check that the app you're uninstalling is bad by looking it up online to see whether or not other users have experienced the same problem. To avoid errors with apps, make sure you only download apps from the Google Play Store (or Galaxy Store, Amazon App Store, etc). Downloading apps from unofficial sources may increase the chances of installing malware or viruses on your phone.

steps.title: Open your Android's Settings.
steps.content: Open your Android's Settings. Swipe down from the top of the screen to open the Notifications shade and then tap the Settings/Gear icon in the upper-right corner.

steps.title: Scroll down and tap Apps.
steps.content: Scroll down and tap Apps . You'll find this in the middle of the Settings page. On some Androids, you'll tap Apps & notifications instead.

steps.title: Select the app that's giving you trouble.
steps.content: Select the app that's giving you trouble. You'll see a list of all the apps you have installed. Tap the app that you want to uninstall. Its page will open an information page. You may have to scroll down to find the app. On some Androids, you may have to tap App info before proceeding.

steps.title: Tap Force Stop or if needed.
steps.content: Tap Force Stop or if needed. If the app is running, you'll need to stop it. Tap Force Stop at the bottom of the screen to do so. This option may say Disable on some Android devices. If this option is greyed out, then the app is already not running.

steps.title: Tap Storage.
steps.content: Tap Storage . It's on the app information page. Tap this option to display the Storage options.

steps.title: Tap Clear cache.
steps.content: Tap Clear cache . It's at the bottom of the page. This will erase any cached data the app has saved. That way you won't have any residual data after you uninstall the app.

steps.title: Tap Clear data.
steps.content: Tap Clear data . It's the second option at the bottom of the page. This will delete any files or saved data the app has created.

steps.title: Return to the app info page.
steps.content: Return to the app info page. To do so, tap the icon pointing left in the upper-left corner. This will take you back to the previous page.

steps.title: Tap Uninstall.
steps.content: Tap Uninstall . It's the button that has an icon that resembles a trashcan. It's at the bottom of the page. This will display a pop-up window. If the app won't uninstall, you may need to tap Force Stop or Disable at the bottom of the screen.

steps.title: Tap Uninstall when prompted.
steps.content: Tap Uninstall when prompted. Doing so will remove the app from your Android. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Restart your Android.
steps.content: Restart your Android. You'll need to |restart your phone for the changes to take effect. When the Android finishes restarting, Safe Mode should be turned off again.

steps.title: Open the Settings menu.
steps.content: Open the Settings menu. To do so, swipe down from the top of the screen. Then tap the icon that resembles a gear in the upper-right corner. If you've tried everything and your phone is still stuck in Safe Mode, there may be a software issue. You'll need to factory reset your phone. This will erase all apps and saved data on your phone. Do this as a last resort. Make sure you back up your phone before resetting it if you are able to.

steps.title: Tap General Management.
steps.content: Tap General Management . It's near the bottom of the Settings menu, you may need to scroll down a bit to find it. On some devices, this may be under the " System " menu. The Settings menu is different from one phone manufacturer to the next. Consult your user's manual or manufacturer's web page to learn how to factory reset your specific phone model.

steps.title: Tap Reset or Reset options.
steps.content: Tap Reset or Reset options . It's near the bottom of the General Management menu.

steps.title: Tap Factory data reset or Erase all data.
steps.content: Tap Factory data reset or Erase all data . It's at the bottom of the menu.

steps.title: Tap Reset Device or Erase all data.
steps.content: Tap Reset Device or Erase all data . It's at the bottom of the page. This will factory reset your phone and restore it's factory settings. This process is irreversible. You may need to enter your PIN or passcode. When your phone restarts, you will need to go through the process of setting up your phone again. If you have a backup saved, you will be given the option to restore your phone from the backup during the setup process. If your phone is still stuck in Safe Mode after factory resetting it, there is most likely something wrong with the hardware. You will need to have your phone repaired or replaced. Contact your mobile carrier or point of sale to see if your phone is still under warranty.
